unnormalised: The quest for the perfect mileage figure. Ah, a journey filled with more twists and turns than the roads of the Himalayas! It's the national obsession, isn't it? "Kitna deti hai?" is practically the first question you ask before even checking the colour of a car.

unnormalised: We Indians, masters of Jugaad, have perfected the art of stretching every drop of petrol to its absolute limit. I remember my uncle, Sharma ji, would boast his old Maruti 800 gave him 25 kmpl (kilometers per liter) in the city. Of course, this was achieved by driving at a steady 40 km/h (kilometers per hour), windows up, AC off (even in Delhi summer at 40 deg C), and drafting behind DTC buses. Efficiency at its finest (or torture, depending on your perspective).
normalised: We Indians, masters of Jugaad, have perfected the art of stretching every drop of petrol to its absolute limit. I remember my uncle, Sharma ji, would boast his old Maruti eight hundred gave him twenty five kilometers per liter in the city. Of course, this was achieved by driving at a steady forty kilometers per hour, windows up, A-C off (even in Delhi summer at forty degree celsius), and drafting behind D-T-C buses. Efficiency at its finest (or torture, depending on your perspective).

unnormalised: Then there's the great CNG vs. Petrol debate. CNG (Compressed Natural Gas), the saviour of our wallets, especially here in Delhi. Auto-rickshaw walas swear by it, claiming they get an unbelievable 35 km/kg (kilometers per kilogram). This might be true, or it might be a masterful exaggeration passed down through generations. Who really knows? All I know is it saves them some ₹ (Indian Rupees) to fill their tanks.

Who really knows? All I know is it saves them some Indian Rupees to fill their tanks.

unnormalised: The truth, like the mythical unicorn, is hard to find. Car manufacturers claim one thing, ARAI (Automotive Research Association of India) figures suggest another, and what you actually get in real-world conditions is often a comedy of errors. You see, even those 1.2 litre engines struggle if you put five people in the back and then drive up a mountain. Who’d have thought!?

You see, even those one point two liter engines struggle if you put five people in the back and then drive up a mountain. Who'd have thought!?

unnormalised: And let's not forget the effect of that ever-tempting "AC on full blast" button. The sweet, sweet relief from the Indian heat comes at a cost, a hefty dip in the fuel economy. Suddenly, your cherished 20 kmpl is down to a meager 15 kmpl. Decisions, decisions... comfort or saving ₹. 100 (Indian Rupees) at the pump? A tough choice!

unnormalised: My college friend, Gupta, even tried some crazy fuel-saving hacks. He’d push his scooter uphill, coast downhill with the engine off, and even attempted to add some weird "fuel booster" he bought from a shady guy on the side of the road. Let's just say that experiment ended with a sputtering engine and a costly trip to the mechanic. Turns out that 10 ml (millilitres) fuel booster was nothing but colored water…

unnormalised: So, what's the secret to achieving that elusive high mileage number? Well, there isn't one. Drive smoothly, maintain your car, avoid unnecessary acceleration, and maybe, just maybe, you'll get a figure that's close to what the manufacturer claims. Or, you know, just embrace the chaos and enjoy the ride, even if it costs you a little extra ₹. afterall, a full tank and a samosa is a lot better than saving ₹ 500!
